# 1. Company Overview (NOW) - Comprehensive Analysis Report

## 1. Company Overview

ServiceNow, Inc. is an American software company that supplies a cloud computing platform for the creation and management of automated business workflows. The company was founded in Santa Clara, California, United States, in 2003 by Fred Luddy. Its core offering is the "Now Platform," an intelligent, cloud-based platform that enables organizations to automate, manage, and optimize a wide array of business processes across IT, HR, customer service, and more.

ServiceNow's business model is predominantly subscription-based, offering clients access to its cloud services and solutions through annual or multi-year contracts. It is listed on the New York Stock Exchange (ticker symbol: NOW) and is a constituent of the S&P 100 and S&P 500 indices. By 2025, ServiceNow articulated a strategic vision to evolve into an "AI-powered enterprise nerve center," emphasizing "Agentic AI." From global enterprises to public sector leaders, nearly 8,400 organizations and more than 85% of the Fortune 500® companies trust ServiceNow to help them work smarter, move faster, and deliver extraordinary outcomes.

## 3. Existing Products/Services

ServiceNow's platform is organized around four main workflow solutions:

• **IT Workflows**: ITSM: The comprehensive ITSM suite includes a Configuration Management Database (CDM), knowledge management, "Now Assist" generative AI support, change management, incident management, predictive intelligence, and more. ITOM: A full IT Operations Management kit with certificate management, service mapping, discovery, firewalls, reporting tools, and metric intelligence. SPM: A Strategic Portfolio Management solution that combines scenario and strategic planning with investment funding insights, agile development, scaled agile frameworks, collaborative tools, and data capture solutions.

• **Employee Workflows**: human resources, legal, and workplace service delivery products

• **Customer Workflows**: customer service management product; and field service management applications

• **Security & Risk**: Security and risk business -- Now surpasses $1 billion in ACV, becoming the fifth ServiceNow business to cross that threshold.

The company operates the Now platform, an AI platform for digital transformation machine learning, robotic process automation, process mining, analytics, and low-code/no-code development tools.

## 4. Planned Products/Services/Projects

AI-Powered Platform Evolution: Unveiling the "ServiceNow AI Platform" to integrate any AI, agent, and model across the enterprise. Agentic AI: Focusing on autonomous AI agents that observe, decide, and trigger workflows. By the end of 2025, ServiceNow will have 1,000+ AI agents working autonomously and proactively across technology, customer & employee, creator workflows, and others.

Workflow Data Fabric and RaptorDB: Unifying business and technology data for AI and analytics. At Knowledge 2025, the company introduced an AI Control Tower offering a unified dashboard for business leaders to monitor AI agents running across enterprise systems, track adoption metrics and ensure governance compliance.

GenAI products like Now Assist targeting $1 billion in ACV by 2026. This growth was fueled by the "Xanadu" and "Yokohama" platform releases, which introduced agents capable of resolving complex IT outages and HR requests without human intervention.

## 5. Growth Strategy

ServiceNow's growth strategy centers on several key pillars:

• **AI-Powered Transformation**: Market Expansion and Innovation: Aggressively expanding into HR, customer service, security operations, and launching a reimagined CRM solution.

• **Strategic Acquisitions**: It has spent at least $12 billion this year on acquisitions or strategic investments.

• **Platform Integration**: The platform is expanding into crucial cross-enterprise workflows, solidifying its role as an enterprise-wide orchestration engine.

• **Federal/Government Expansion**: The company's federal business grew more than 30% year over year in the third quarter of 2025, demonstrating strength in a traditionally challenging market segment that many software companies struggle to penetrate effectively.

## 6. Current and Potential Major Clients

AT&T, Walmart, CVS Health, Coca-Cola, Goldman Sachs Group, JP Morgan Chase, Microsoft and Morgan Stanley are some of the prominent Fortune 500 Companies that are using ServiceNow. ServiceNow Clients include United States Department of Defense, Walmart, Amazon.com, Apple Inc, CVS Health and many others.

ServiceNow serves 85% of the Fortune 500 companies as of 2023. The average annual contract value for large enterprises is $1.2 million. Healthcare Clients: 60% of top 100 healthcare organizations · Financial Services Clients: 70% of global top 50 banks

The company had 103 transactions over $1 million in net new annual contract value ("ACV") in Q3, and ended the quarter with 553 customers with more than $5 million in ACV, representing 18% year‑over‑year growth.

### Annual Performance:
Since its IPO, ServiceNow has experienced impressive growth, with revenues reaching $10.98 billion in 2024 and expanding its global footprint, serving over 85% of Fortune 500 companies.

Full-year outlook raised -- Subscription revenue guidance increased by $55 million to a midpoint of $12.840 billion (20.5% growth) for fiscal 2025 (ending December 31, 2025); operating margin goal raised by 50 basis points to 31%, and free cash flow margin goal up by 200 basis points to 34%.

ServiceNow, which debuted on the Fortune 500 in 2023 and last year moved up 67 spots, has grown its subscription revenue at a 26% compound annual growth rate from 2020 to 2024, reaching $10.6 billion last year.

## 8. Market Shares

ServiceNow dominates the ITSM space with over 50% market share, offering native capabilities for incident management, problem resolution, and service delivery. The company currently dominates the ITSM space with an over 50% market share; they are both a well-respected player in this space.

ServiceNow achieved a score of 54%, making it the only company in its peer group, which includes Workday (42%), Salesforce (42%), Microsoft (42%), Oracle (24%), and SAP (22%) to exceed the Rule of 50 benchmark.

IDC has named Salesforce the biggest CRM provider in the world for the 12th year running. Figures from its 2025 Worldwide Semiannual Software Tracker show that Salesforce earned over $21.6BN in CRM revenues last year. Microsoft is the nearest rival, earning $5.45BN in 2024, almost four times less than Salesforce. ServiceNow is entering this competitive CRM market.

## 10. Partnerships, Mergers and Acquisitions

### 2025 Major Acquisitions:
Under the terms of the definitive agreement, ServiceNow has agreed to acquire Armis for approximately $7.75 billion in cash, subject to customary adjustments. ServiceNow expects to fund the transaction through a combination of cash on hand and debt. The company has surpassed $340 million in annual recurring revenue (ARR), with year-over-year ARR growth exceeding 50%.

ServiceNow also closed its acquisition of Moveworks on December 15 for $2.85 billion, consisting of $2.61 billion in cash and $0.24 billion in stock.

On December 2, ServiceNow agreed to acquire Veza, enhancing its capabilities in identity security. According to The Information, the purchase price is between $1 billion and $1.5 billion, though exact terms were not officially disclosed.

### Strategic Partnerships:
Partnerships and Ecosystem: Deepening integrations with NVIDIA, Microsoft, Google, and Oracle. The company expanded its strategic partnership with NTT DATA and designated them as a strategic AI delivery partner to accelerate AI-led transformation for enterprises globally.

## 11. Recent Developments

### Stock Split:
A five-for-one stock split, effective December 18, 2025, aims to increase share accessibility.

### AI Product Momentum:
AI customer adoption -- 1,700 customers are live on Now Assist as of Q3. McDermott described ServiceNow's position as "the AI workflow company" and stated, "our AI products are on pace to exceed half a billion in ACV this year,"

This also included a 55x increase in AI Agent Assist consumption in the past five months.

### Office Expansion:
In September 2025, ServiceNow announced that it was expanding into Florida, with a new office location in West Palm Beach.

### Leadership:
Mastantuono was named President while continuing as CFO in 2025.

### Federal Initiatives:
With this deal, ServiceNow can provide government-wide agencies with its products including its AI and workflow solutions, allowing more agencies to use ServiceNow due to faster implementation. In return, ServiceNow has estimated to save the federal government billions over the coming five years, by boosting its overall efficiency levels by 30%.

## 12. AI Investment Rating & Fair Value Assessment

### Strengths:
• Dominant market position with high customer stickiness, robust financials (low debt, high cash flow), AI-driven innovation, and platform versatility.
• Strong Q3 2025 performance with revenue and margin growth acceleration
• Market-leading AI adoption with Now Assist gaining significant traction
• Expanding beyond core ITSM into CRM, security, and federal markets
• Impressive customer base with 85% Fortune 500 penetration

### Risks and Concerns:
• Recent stock volatility and valuation concerns (high P/E), investor apprehension regarding the proposed $7 billion Armis acquisition, intense competitive pressure and potential AI disruption to its business model (e.g., "seat count pressure"), and execution risk in AI adoption.
• Investors fear that CEO McDermott is relying too heavily on acquisitions for growth. Matthew Hedberg, an analyst at RBC Capital Markets, suggests that the acquisition is being used to boost slowing revenue growth.
• High valuation multiples creating elevated expectations

### Fair Value Assessment:
Based on current fundamentals and growth trajectory:
- ServiceNow's narrative projects $20.3 billion revenue and $3.3 billion earnings by 2028. This requires 18.9% yearly revenue growth and approximately $1.6 billion earnings increase from $1.7 billion today.
- Strong AI momentum with Now Assist targeting $1 billion ACV by 2026
- Consistent 20%+ revenue growth with expanding margins
- Market-leading position in workflow automation

**Buy Rating: 7/10**

**Estimated Fair Value: $185-200**

The rating reflects ServiceNow's strong market position, AI-driven growth potential, and expanding addressable market, balanced against valuation concerns and acquisition integration risks. The company is well-positioned for continued growth as AI adoption accelerates across enterprises, though execution on recent acquisitions and maintaining growth rates amid increased competition will be critical for achieving the higher end of the fair value range.
tldr_summary:
ServiceNow is a cloud-based software company providing workflow automation platforms across IT, HR, customer service, and security for enterprises, serving 85% of Fortune 500 companies. 

The company is aggressively expanding its AI capabilities, targeting $1 billion in AI product annual contract value by 2026 through its "Now Platform" and strategic acquisitions like Armis ($7.75B) and Moveworks ($2.85B). With a dominant 50%+ market share in IT service management and strong growth in emerging markets like federal/government sectors, ServiceNow is positioning itself as an enterprise AI workflow leader. Key competitive advantages include deep enterprise integration, robust AI agent technologies, and a comprehensive platform that enables cross-functional workflow automation.

Recent significant developments include expanding strategic partnerships with NVIDIA, Microsoft, and Google, and introducing autonomous AI agents capable of proactively resolving complex business requests. ServiceNow receives a 7/10 buy rating with a fair value estimate of $185-$200, reflecting strong growth potential balanced against valuation risks.
